subject: Re: Multithreading: Testing scheduled method invocation?!
msgSnippet: Michael, sounds like a variation on what I have done. Check out the Channel and FutureResult classes if you want to pass something back to the main thread
messageBody:
Michael,

sounds like a variation on what I have done. Check out the Channel and
FutureResult classes if you want to pass something back to the main
thread (e.g. an event object) in order to assert something.

Nevertheless, multithreaded testing is a pain in the neck and I have
since converted these tests to be single threaded.

- Neil Swingler


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Michael Schuerig <michael@s...> wrote:
>
> I'm working on a class that interacts with the Spring framework's
> application context and the Quartz scheduler. I'm pretty new to the
> latter, thus I'm testing my understanding of Quartz just as much as I'm
> testing my code. In effect, I can't (yet) build the fixture for my code
> completely with mocks as I have to ascertain what these mocks are
> supposed to do first.
>
> The complication here is that Quartz uses its own "hidden" thread(s) to
> fulfill its duties. It is such a thread that effects the change that I
> need to check for. As I don't want to test Quartz, of course, I'm
> content with checking that my scheduled job is executed at all. Thus I
> schedule it for immediate execution, wait for 2 secs to give Quartz
> some time before the fixture is torn down again.
>
> Now, all this works surprisingly well. Still, I don't like the part of
> waiting some arbitrary time.
>
> (Thinking break)
>
> After getting this far, I remembered that Doug Lea's concurrency utils
> have made their way into J2SE 5.0 and there I found just what I needed:
> java.util.concurrent.CountDownLatch
>
> Now I have a TestCase that looks in outline like this
>
>
> public class MultiThreadedTest extends TestCase {
> private static CountDownLatch latch;
> private MyMock mock;
>
> protected void setUp() {
> latch = new CountDownLatch(1);
> mock = new MyMock();
> }
>
> public void testMe() throws Exception {
> startSomeWorkInAnotherThread(mock);
> latch.await(); // some timeout might be prudent
> mock.verify();
> }
>
>
> private static class MyMock implements Whatever {
> private boolean wasCalled = false;
>
> public void methodCalledFromOtherThread() {
> wasCalled = true;
> latch.countDown();
> }
>
> public void verify() {
> assertTrue(wasCalled);
> }
> }
> }
>
